We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The petechial rash and low platelet count suggest a diagnosis of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). In a child with newly diagnosed ITP who is not actively bleeding, the first-line management is observation as 80% of cases resolve spontaneously within 6 months without any specific treatment. IVIg or corticosteroids may be considered if bleeding develops or if the platelet count drops below 30,000/mm3. Rituximab or splenectomy are considered second-line treatment options for refractory or chronic cases.
